articles.title: Trump announces full pardon for Virginia sheriff convicted of bribery

neutral.headline: President Trump Issues Pardon to Former Virginia Sheriff Convicted of Bribery
neutral.body:
In a surprising move, President Trump granted a full pardon on Monday to former Virginia sheriff Scott Jenkins, who had been convicted of bribery. The decision came with Trump citing concerns of a "weaponized" Justice Department under the Biden administration.
Jenkins, who served as sheriff in Culpeper County, was convicted of accepting bribes in exchange for favors during his time in office. Trump's decision to pardon him has sparked debate among legal experts and the public.
While some view the pardon as a gesture of leniency towards a former law enforcement officer, others criticize it as undermining the judicial system's integrity. The Trump administration has defended the pardon, stating that Jenkins was unfairly targeted by the Justice Department's alleged politicization.
As the debate continues to unfold, the implications of Trump's pardon of Jenkins remain uncertain. Critics argue that it sets a dangerous precedent for undermining the rule of law, while supporters believe it highlights the need for reform within the Justice Department.
